page.title: 08A WELSH MOUNTAIN FARM. cont.
page.content: {Sheep dipping }time is also a very busy time for the Davies family. At the beginning of July sheep must be dipped to prevent diseases like sheep scab and to stop maggot flies laying their eggs in the sheep's wool. The sheep are pushed into a large bath filled with a special disinfectant. Sheep are weighed and when they are fat enough they are taken to Builth Wells, 50 miles away, to be slaughtered. When new stock has to be bought the Davies' visit Neath or Carmarthen markets. In the winter the animals are kept in sheds and fed on silage. This is grass which has been cut, put into big piles, clamped and sealed in airtight bags. The Davies' do not have machinery for this so they have contractors to do it.
